class.name: Word.DropCap
class.description: Represents a dropped capital letter in a Word document.

properties.name: context
properties.description: The request context associated with the object. This connects the add-in's process to the Office host application's process.

examples.description: Access the request context from a DropCap object to load and read its properties

properties.name: distanceFromText
properties.description: Gets the distance (in points) between the dropped capital letter and the paragraph text.

examples.description: Get the distance between the drop cap and the paragraph text and display it to the user.

properties.name: fontName
properties.description: Gets the name of the font for the dropped capital letter.

examples.description: Get the font name of the dropped capital letter in the first paragraph and display it in the console

properties.name: linesToDrop
properties.description: Gets the height (in lines) of the dropped capital letter.

examples.description: Get the height in lines of the first paragraph's drop cap and display it in the console.

properties.name: position
properties.description: Gets the position of the dropped capital letter.

examples.description: Check if a paragraph has a drop cap applied and display its position (None, Normal, or Margin) in the console.

methods.name: clear
methods.description: Removes the dropped capital letter formatting.

examples.description: Remove the drop cap formatting from the first paragraph in the document

methods.name: enable
methods.description: Formats the first character in the specified paragraph as a dropped capital letter.

examples.description: Format the first character of the first paragraph in the document as a drop cap

methods.name: load
methods.description: Queues up a command to load the specified properties of the object. You must call context.sync() before reading the properties.

params.name: options
params.description: Provides options for which properties of the object to load.

params.name: propertyNames
params.description: A comma-delimited string or an array of strings that specify the properties to load.

params.name: propertyNamesAndPaths
params.description: propertyNamesAndPaths.select is a comma-delimited string that specifies the properties to load, and propertyNamesAndPaths.expand is a comma-delimited string that specifies the navigation properties to load.

examples.description: Load and display the text and number of lines for the first paragraph's drop cap

methods.name: toJSON
methods.description: Overrides the JavaScript toJSON() method in order to provide more useful output when an API object is passed to JSON.stringify(). (JSON.stringify, in turn, calls the toJSON method of the object that's passed to it.) Whereas the original Word.DropCap object is an API object, the toJSON method returns a plain JavaScript object (typed as Word.Interfaces.DropCapData) that contains shallow copies of any loaded child properties from the original object.

examples.description: Get the drop cap properties of the first paragraph and log them as a JSON string to the console.

methods.name: track
methods.description: Track the object for automatic adjustment based on surrounding changes in the document. This call is a shorthand for context.trackedObjects.add(thisObject). If you're using this object across .sync calls and outside the sequential execution of a ".run" batch, and get an "InvalidObjectPath" error when setting a property or invoking a method on the object, you need to add the object to the tracked object collection when the object was first created. If this object is part of a collection, you should also track the parent collection.

examples.description: Track a drop cap object across multiple sync calls to modify its properties without getting an InvalidObjectPath error

methods.name: untrack
methods.description: Release the memory associated with this object, if it has previously been tracked. This call is shorthand for context.trackedObjects.remove(thisObject). Having many tracked objects slows down the host application, so please remember to free any objects you add, once you're done using them. You'll need to call context.sync() before the memory release takes effect.

examples.description: Track a drop cap object to modify its properties, then untrack it to release memory after the modifications are complete.
